12.text:
My definition of identity is basically
what you see on the screen here.

21.text:
And the best way I can describe this
is by telling you a little bit of a story.

25.text:
Now, some of you in this room
probably know my story.

28.text:
Some of you have been part of my story.
You're sat just up here.

33.text:
At the age of ten years old,
I went away to school.

37.text: My parents were both in the military,

39.text:
and I left what was
a very supportive, loving family

43.text: to go to boarding school here in the UK.

46.text:
The reason for that was because
the schooling had finished in Germany,

51.text:
and they didn't have a choice
than sending me to school here,

55.text: and it nearly ripped my family apart.

68.text: I lost my sense of adventure, my passion,

74.text:
and I ended up becoming
an easy target for bullies.

83.text: you're supposed to be in a loving family,

85.text:
you're supposed to have
that support around you,

87.text: and I just didn't have that.

91.text:
So, I was in this boarding school,
in Nottinghamshire,

95.text:
and I was waking up every morning
not going to see my parents,

101.text: having a constant level of torment

103.text:
about the fact that I was
different to other people.

106.text:
I didn't have the right haircut,
I didn't have the right shoes,

110.text:
I didn't have the millions of pounds that
some other kids at my school actually had.

117.text:
and this made me start
to question who I was,

121.text: whether or not I was good enough.

126.text:
The bullying started
very much as a name-calling.

132.text:
It then quickly progressed
to physical bullying.

136.text:
I was finding myself getting beaten up
near enough on a daily basis,

141.text:
being chased into areas
which I thought were my sanctuary:

147.text: I couldn't get away from it,

149.text:
but then, at the age of 13,
I had an opportunity to change school.

159.text: I changed school, but guess what:

166.text:
At the age of 13, I started
to figure out who I was,

174.text:
that maybe I was a little bit
more different to other people.

180.text: I figured out that I was gay,

183.text:
and to be perfectly honest with you,
that terrified the life out of me,

187.text: genuinely terrified the life out of me.

193.text:
My school didn't talk about homosexuality.
They didn't talk about being gay.

198.text:
I had to look it up on the internet.
I didn't know what it was.

202.text:
I thought it was an illness,
I thought it was a disease,

205.text:
because when they did talk about it,
it was spoken about so negatively

210.text:
that there was something wrong with me,
clearly there was something wrong with me.

219.text:
Because I was so scared
about being gay, I hid it.

223.text: I hid my true self, my true identity,

227.text: the basic make-up of what makes me me.

232.text: And at the age of 18, this got so much

236.text: that there was only one answer,

239.text: and that was to try and take my own life.

243.text:
One Sunday afternoon,
I went down to dinner in the hall,

253.text: I went back up to my bedroom,

259.text:
and I had every intention
of ending it then,

264.text: because I couldn't be who I was.

273.text: I'm not a figment of your imagination.

277.text:
There was a knock at my door,
and when I went to my door,

280.text:
I opened it up 
and there was nobody there.

286.text:
but, call it divine intervention,
call it fate, whatever you want,

289.text: something stopped me from doing it.

294.text: I quickly fell into a depressive state,

298.text:
I had a nervous breakdown
and I was pulled out of school.

302.text: It kind of all came out -

308.text:
but I still didn't tell people
that I was gay.

315.text:
All the way through my 20s,
I led a depressive life.

318.text: I felt that, if I wanted to be happy -

324.text:
was, if you wanted to be successful
and you wanted to be happy,

328.text:
you needed to be straight,
you needed to be married,

331.text:
you needed to have kids,
you needed to have a mortgage,

334.text:
have a good car, a good job,
a pension plan.

346.text: I didn't have kids. That didn't work.

351.text:
And then, at the age of 29,
it all came crashing down,

355.text: and that was the start of my life,

357.text:
that was the start
of me finding my identity.

360.text:
I had what they call a TIA,
which is a transient ischemic attack,

372.text: so very different to what I am now.

374.text: I hated sport, I hated running.

380.text:
I had no visions, no objectives,
no wants in my life,

383.text:
and I was sat in a hospital bed,
in the Bristol Royal Infirmary,

388.text:
thinking, "I'm 29 years old,
and I haven't got a clue who I am."

395.text:
It's like one of those Hollywood moments
when you suddenly have a Eureka moment,

401.text:
but unfortunately, in Hollywood,
it's all OK afterwards.

405.text:
The reality is that you spend
about two or three years

408.text:
trying to figure out
how to uncondition yourself

410.text: from the ways that you've been acting.

415.text: I got divorced and I started my life.

425.text:
I spent most of that time
moaning and groaning the fact

428.text:
that I should probably 
get fit and healthy,

431.text: but not actually doing anything about it.

434.text:
Probably quite a few people in this room
that take out a gym membership in January

438.text:
go for two weeks
and then don't go after that.

444.text:
But then, a friend of mine
got absolutely sick and tired of me,

450.text:
and basically dragged me down
to a running club,

453.text: and that was four years ago,

455.text: and that was where my life changed.

458.text: I found something that I could call mine.

464.text: Everything in my life to date

467.text:
had been done because somebody else
wanted me to do it.

470.text:
Because I had no identity,
because I had no clue who I was,

474.text: I'd been influenced by other people.

477.text: Now, I was taking back control.

482.text: I started to run every week,

484.text:
and within about six months,
I'd run my first marathon.

488.text: It sounds a bit crazy, I know,

491.text:
but I loved it, it was
my sense of escapism,

495.text:
it was my sense
of communicating to the world,

500.text:
like we've seen with some of the people
that have spoken already today.

510.text:
So, how did I get from that to running
401 marathons in 401 days?

515.text: It's a bit of a leap,

518.text: but for me it was an organic process.

523.text: I'd spent so long hiding who I truly was

525.text:
that, the moment that I had
an opportunity to be who I wanted to be,

530.text:
I was going to grab it
with both hands and go for it.

533.text:
So, the decision was easy.
I'd found a passion in running.

537.text: I knew I wanted to help charities

540.text:
that were related to the issues
that I'd faced at school.

543.text:
So, I decided that I was going
to give my job up,

546.text: I was going to sell my house,

548.text:
I was going to sell
everything that I owned

550.text: and rid myself of my previous life

554.text: to go and have an adventure of a lifetime.

557.text:
On the first of September last year,
I started in Bristol,

562.text: and I ran 10,500 miles over 401 days.

567.text:
That was one marathon,
26.2 miles, every single day.

572.text: I even ran in Macclesfield twice.

574.text:
I believe there are some people from
the Macc Harriers here that I ran with.

578.text:
I got to meet 9,500 people that took part
in the challenge that I did.

584.text:
It was my idea. It was my plan.
It was what I wanted to do with life.

591.text:
We wanted to inspire people,
we wanted to challenge people,

595.text:
get them to do something,
think differently,

598.text: try something they'd never done before.

602.text: We had over 1,500 people run further

606.text:
than they've ever run 
in their entire life,

608.text:
and I'm talking people who only turned up
in the morning to run a couple of miles,

614.text:
and by the end of the day,
they'd run their first marathon.

622.text: What I found from my experience

624.text:
was everything about what
you think is in your head.

635.text:
it's based on experiences
you've had in life.

639.text:
That might seem quite simple,
that might seem quite obvious,

644.text: but it's no more complicated than that.

654.text:
finding something that made me
happy to my soul, happy to my heart;

660.text:
the fact that I knew
that, if I could do it every day,

663.text: for the rest of my life,

665.text:
I wouldn't struggle getting out
of bed in the morning;

668.text:
finding that brought
a sense of peace to my life.

673.text: It brought a sense of order.

677.text:
It helped me think about things
in a completely different way,

680.text:
look at things in a completely
different perspective.

684.text: It helped me accept who I was.

689.text: At school, being a gay man,

692.text: I was made to feel as though I was weak,

698.text: that I didn't belong on this Earth.

704.text: No kid should ever have to feel that way,

707.text: ever have to feel that way.

711.text: But now, I stand here before you

714.text:
having done something that nobody else
has ever done in the world,

722.text: feeling proud of who I am,

725.text:
and not having the feeling like I have
to shove it down everybody's neck.

731.text: I'm confident with who I am.

733.text: I'm passionate about what I do in life.

737.text:
I might not have a clue
where I want to go next,

740.text:
because it's only been a month
since the challenge ended,

749.text: Identity, for me, is true happiness.

755.text: I'll leave you with one question.
